comments:
I200412162000, maybe connected to bug 77589.
Found when trying to reproduce bug 81348.

- new workspace, new project, new CU p/A.java:
package p;
public class A {
	A a;
}

- Open A.java in java editor and rename type A to B
  (cannot reproduce when editor is closed)
- Quickly repeat pressing Alt+Shift+Z and Alt+Shift+Y

From time to time, 3 strange things happens (sometimes alone, sometimes together):

a) B.java has correct contents. The open editor is a blank editor for A.java.
Closing the editor makes A.java disappear also in the Package Explorer. Looks
like an editor on an empty working copy for A.java

b) undo/redo fails due to a MalformedTreeException:

I think this is related to 77589. As soon we have a fix for 77589 we have to
check if we can recreate the malformed tree exception.

I restested it and I counldn't reproduce the failures b.) and c.). This is
exprected given that bug 77589 got fixed (without fix workspace wasn't properly
looked).

However, I was ablw to reproduce failure a which is a stale Java editor. It only
happens when the "block dialog" appears. May be it is a problem since the block
dialog processes SWT events.

Moving to text for comments.

Could reproduce and filed bug 82462 for the stale/empty editor (without getting
an exception). However, when testing with the following source:

package p;
public class A {
}

I again run into the same errors outlined in b) and c). I can reproduce b) and
c) even with closed editor and while debugging: I put a breakpoint into
Resource.move(...) line 1212. This breakpoint gets hit and the stack trace below
shows that the indexer causes this problem because it accesses the file without
using scheduling rules:

Unfortunately the indexing thread cannot take a lock on the resource as this
would cause a deadlock in the scenario where the user renames a type:
1. The main thread takes the lock on /P/p (so as to modify A.java)
2. The indexing thread attempts to lock /P/p/A.java (so as to read its contents)
3. The main thread proceeds and search for references to A.
4. The search needs to wait for the indexing to finish to get accurate results
(WAIT_UNTIL_READY option of the SearchEngine)
This is deadlock situation.

There is no solution to this problem at the JDT Core level as JDT Core doesn't
own the lock taken in step 1.

Jerome,

a solution could be the new API to transfer rules between threads. Since the
main thread is waiting it could hand over his rules to the search thread so that
it can proceed. However this would require new/additional API and clients that
cooperate.

I was not aware of such API and I could not find anything in bugzilla. Is there
a bug entered for this new API ?

The API is IJobManager#transferRule(...).

The corresponding bug report is bug 82585.

Reopening to consider. 

I'm not sure that I understand completly how the API works. A first approach
would be as follows: when the index manager waits for a job to finish (either in
discardJobs() or in performConcurrentJob()), it would get the scheduling rule
from this job, and transfer the scheduling rule to the indexing thread.
